CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Extradition;Positive obligations) (Uzbekistan);Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Effective investigation;Extradition) (Procedural aspect);No violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1-f - Extradition);No violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-4 - Review of lawfulness of detention);Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-4 - Review of lawfulness of detention);No violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-4 - Speediness of review);Violation of Article 34 - Individual applications (Article 34 - Hinder the exercise of the right of petition);Non-pecuniary damage - award (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage)
JUDGES: Dmitry Dedov;Elisabeth Steiner;Erik Møse;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Khanlar Hajiyev;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Ksenija Turković
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE . Until DATE he was detained in PERSON . He is currently held in detention in GPE , GPE .

CARDINAL . Until DATE the applicant and his family were living in LOC of LOC , located in LOC of GPE . He transported goods to the nearby villages in a cart pulled by a donkey . The applicant is a practising NORP . In DATE he started performing PERSON and attending a mosque .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant ’s passport ( “ the old passport ” ) expired , and , to apply for its renewal , he completed a “ form no . CARDINAL ” , a questionnaire containing his personal details and the old passport number . On DATE he was issued with a new passport ( “ the current passport ” ) . The original form no . CARDINAL was filed at the local branch of ORG , GPE .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , in DATE he learned of the arrest of a neighbour with whom he had regularly performed PERSON . Being aware of the widespread practice of torture in detention in GPE , he decided to leave the country for fear of arrest on fabricated charges and torture in custody .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant arrived in GPE via ORG ( “ FAC ” ) . On DATE he was issued with a temporary residence permit valid until DATE . He lived in GPE in ORG , until his arrest . His wife and a minor daughter live in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of the ORG brought criminal proceedings against a group of persons , apparently including the applicant , on suspicion of setting up a criminal group attempting to overthrow the constitutional order of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the above - mentioned department issued CARDINAL separate formal statements of charges against the applicant . Both decisions specified that he had been charged in absentia with involving minors in criminal activity ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( b ) of LAW of GPE ( “ the ORG ” ) ) , terrorism ( LAW ) , incitement to hatred and hostility giving rise to discrimination on grounds of race and religion by an organised group and by means dangerous to the public ( LAW ) , conspiracy to overthrow the NORP State ’s constitutional order ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) , unlawful crossing of the State border ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( b ) ) , repeated forgery of official documents and use of the fabricated documents ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( a ) , ( b ) ) , setting up a criminal group ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) , producing and disseminating documents containing ideas of religious extremism , separatism and fundamentalism , and threats to national security and public order ( Article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) § CARDINAL ( a ) of the ORG ) , setting up , managing and participating in extremist , separatist , fundamentalist and other banned organisations ( LAW ) § CARDINAL of the ORG ) , and smuggling material disseminating extremist , separatist and radical fundamentalist ideas ( LAW of the ORG ) .

CARDINAL . The first statement of charges , issued in respect of the applicant only , began with an outline of NORP State policy in the sphere of the fight against religious extremism and , in particular , referred to the events of DATE in LOC as an armed attempt to seize State power conducted by members of the extremist movement “ PERSON with the assistance of international terrorist forces and “ under the influence of certain GPE acting on the basis of double standards and seeking to achieve their own geopolitical aims ” . It further described actions allegedly committed by various individuals identified as members of the criminal group the applicant belonged to . The actions imputed directly to the applicant were described as follows :

“ GPE , with a view to studying the works of the leader of the criminal association ‘ ORG ... and having chosen the path of jihad , met in DATE with residents of LOC of LOC [ CARDINAL names quoted ] and others ... studied the ideas of the religious extremist movement and became member of the extremist movement ‘ PERSON . ”

CARDINAL . In the second statement of charges the investigator listed various actions the applicant had participated in “ as a member of a criminal group ” or “ on the basis of a criminal conspiracy ” . In particular , he was suspected of membership of the banned religious movement “ Wahhabism ” , studying materials by ORG , spreading ideas of religious extremism , disseminating and storing video - materials by the abovementioned banned religious movements , and providing financial support to members of the criminal group .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the applicant ’s arrest . On DATE his name was put on the crossborder list of wanted persons by the decision of an investigator of ORG of the ORG . It appears that at some point the applicant was placed on the ORG Fugitives List ( in the absence of further information , see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the police arrested the applicant in ORG as a person on the cross - border wanted list . On the same date the Anti - Terrorism Criminal Investigation Unit of ORG of the ORG confirmed to the NORP authorities the applicant ’s placement on the cross - border wanted list and its intention to request his extradition , enclosing a petition for the applicant ’s arrest and placement in custody , the first statement of charges , his passport details , and a copy of the form no . CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant wrote a letter to the prosecutor ’s office of ORG stating that he had left GPE after the arrest of his neighbour , out of fear that he would also be arrested , tortured and convicted on fabricated charges . He stated that he had gone to GPE in order to earn money , firmly denied all charges against him as fabricated and asked the NORP authorities not to send him to GPE , referring to the risk of torture in detention .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Deputy Prosecutor General of GPE sent a request for the applicant ’s extradition to GPE to ORG . The request contained assurances that the applicant would be prosecuted only for the offences for which he was being extradited , that he would be able to freely leave GPE when he had stood trial and served any sentence , and that he would not be expelled or extradited to a third State without the consent of the NORP authorities . The second statement of charges was enclosed with the request .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Deputy Prosecutor General of GPE reiterated the earlier assurances provided in respect of the case and further assured his NORP counterpart that the applicant would not be prosecuted on political , racial or religious grounds , that he would not be subjected to torture or other inhuman or degrading treatment , and that the guarantees of a fair trial would be observed in the criminal proceedings against him .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the extradition of the applicant to GPE on account of the charges under ORG CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( b ) and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW of GPE ( attempt to overthrow the NORP State ’s constitutional order , participation in and direction of religious , extremist , separatist and other prohibited organisations ) , Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( b ) ( involvement of minors in criminal activity ) , LAW ( terrorism ) , LAW ( incitement to hatred and hostility giving rise to discrimination on grounds of race and religion by an organised group and by means dangerous to the public ) , LAW ( conspiracy to overthrow the NORP State ’s constitutional order ) , LAW ( b ) ( unlawful crossing of the State border ) , LAW setting up a criminal group ) , and LAW producing and disseminating documents containing ideas of religious extremism , separatism and fundamentalism , and threats to national security and public order ) . By the same decision ORG refused the extradition request in so far as it concerned the charges LAW of the ORG ( forgery ) , stating that the alleged offence had been committed by a different person , LAW b ) ( smuggling material disseminating extremist , separatist and radical fundamentalist ideas ) , since the offence was not punishable under LANGUAGE law , and LAW ) § CARDINAL of the ORG ( participating in extremist , separatist , fundamentalist and other banned organisations ) , since the charge was subsumed by another one in accordance with NORP law .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant and his lawyer sought judicial review of the extradition order . They submitted , in particular , that it was unlawful since it had been issued before the applicant ’s request for refugee status had been determined by the domestic authorities . They argued that the “ Wahhabism ” movement was not an organisation banned in GPE and the documents submitted by the NORP authorities lacked information on the applicant ’s membership of a religious organisation after DATE . They pointed out that , according to the decision of CARDINAL DATE , the applicant was charged with several offences as the perpetrator . However , the facts outlined in the statement of charges concerned acts allegedly committed by several other persons , but not by the applicant . They stated that the applicant had been charged with an attempt to overthrow the ORG order of his home country and therefore his criminal prosecution was politically motivated . Finally , referring to the ORG ’s extensive case - law on the matter and various reports by international observers , the defence stressed that the use of torture and ill - treatment against detainees in GPE was systematic and went unpunished by the law - enforcement and security authorities , and that the applicant ran an individualised risk of ill - treatment in the event of extradition .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG upheld the extradition order as lawful and well - founded . The applicant was present , represented , and assisted by an interpreter . During the hearing the applicant maintained that he had a limited command of NORP , and that he had decided to leave GPE after his neighbour ’s arrest out of fear of arrest and torture . He had not applied for refugee status in GPE immediately after his arrival there , since he had at first been unaware of the charges against him and then he had thought that such information would lead to his expulsion from GPE . He had only made such an application after receiving his lawyer ’s advice . The lawyer maintained his grounds for appeal and pointed out that the case - file did not contain the first statement of charges but only the second , which was different from the initial one .

CARDINAL . The defence further requested the admission of PERSON as the applicant ’s defender ( « защитник GPE ) , since she could provide an expert opinion on the situation in GPE and law - enforcement practice in similar cases . The court rejected that request , finding that the applicant was represented by a professional lawyer , and that PERSON was not a member of the applicant ’s family , had only a technical education and did not practise “ in the law - enforcement sphere on extradition matters ” .

CARDINAL . ORG observed that the applicant did not have refugee status in GPE ; he had failed to either apply for it in a timely manner or to advance a plausible explanation for that omission . The court observed that on DATE the ORG Novgorod ORG ( ORG ) had refused to accept his request for an examination on the merits ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , noting that the decision “ was , in substance , correct ” and that it had not been appealed against within the time - limits set out in the domestic law . The court noted , without giving further details , that there was no evidence that the applicant had been , or would be , prosecuted in GPE on political or religious grounds . Turning specifically to the allegation of persecution on political grounds , the court rejected it as having no legal basis . The court noted that , in accordance with the reservation of GPE on ratification of LAW , NORP law did not contain a definition of a “ political offence ” and the list of offences GPE would not consider as “ political ” or “ connected with political offences ” was not exhaustive . Finally , the court found no formal obstacles to the applicant ’s extradition and noted that the NORP authorities had provided assurances in the applicant ’s case .

CARDINAL . On DATE the defence appealed against ORG decision , arguing that the first - instance court had omitted to make a legal assessment of the evidence submitted in support of the argument concerning the risk of ill - treatment in custody . The defence pointed to various discrepancies between the CARDINAL statements of charges constituting the basis for the arrest request and the formal extradition request , respectively , and concluded that the charges had been fabricated . They further argued , on the basis of the first statement of charges , that it did not contain information about offences committed by the applicant but referred to suspicions in respect of other persons . They maintained that the decision to extradite the applicant had been taken unlawfully in the absence of a final ruling in the refugee status proceedings , and also challenged the refusal to admit PERSON as the applicant ’s defender .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyer lodged objections regarding the court hearing transcript , stating , in particular , that the following information had not been included therein : the applicant ’s request for a letter from the ORG High Commissioner for Refugees to be admitted to the case file ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , submissions regarding the applicant ’s limited command of NORP , and a request for a legal assessment of the charges against the applicant . At some point ORG rejected these objections .

CARDINAL . At some point the applicant’ lawyer lodged a request with the office of ORG for clarifications as regards the significant discrepancies in the CARDINAL statements of charges against the applicant . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE ORG informed the applicant that , inter alia , it had requested clarifications on the matter from the office of the of ORG prosecutor . In the meantime , on DATE ORG office of GPE received a letter dated DATE from their NORP counterpart specifying that the applicant ’s extradition was sought only in connection with the offences listed in the formal request for extradition ( apparently , those listed in the second statement of charges ) and asking for the first statement of charges forwarded by the NORP authorities on the date of the applicant ’s arrest in GPE to be disregarded .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE rejected the applicant ’s appeal against the judgment of DATE and upheld the extradition order and ORG decision as lawful and wellfounded . In reaching that conclusion , ORG referred to the assurances by the NORP authorities and noted that ORG of GPE had not pointed out any obstacles to the applicant ’s extradition to GPE . The court found no evidence that the applicant had been , or would be , prosecuted on political or religious grounds and observed that the applicant neither had refugee status nor could be regarded as a person seeking such status in GPE . As regards the alleged discrepancies in the statements of charges provided by the NORP authorities to their NORP counterparts , ORG rejected that argument as irrelevant , since it was not the task of the domestic courts , or the prosecutor ’s office , to decide on the applicant ’s guilt in the extradition proceedings . ORG rejected the request for Ms Ryabinina to be admitted as a defender and questioned as a specialist , upheld ORG refusal to do so and endorsed its reasoning in that respect . The extradition order became final .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a request for refugee status in GPE with ORG on the ground of fear of persecution because of his religious beliefs . He submitted that the accusations against him were unfounded and that he faced torture and other forms of ill - treatment if extradited to GPE . He had left GPE after the arrest of a neighbour with whom he had regularly attended the mosque . He referred to reports by the ORG agencies issued in DATE and reports by respected international NGOs demonstrating that torture was widespread in GPE and confessions were often extracted from defendants under duress . He also referred to the ORG ’s case - law , in particular the case of PERSON and Others v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , DATE ) , concerning extradition to GPE . He specified that he had not applied for refugee status immediately after his arrival in GPE because of his poor command of NORP and also because he had “ not been aware of such a possibility ” .

CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE the ORG NORP ORG advised the applicant that it could not examine his application since he did not meet the “ refugee ” criteria set out in the domestic law . On DATE the applicant challenged that refusal before ORG of GPE ( “ the NORP FMS ” ) , submitting that ORG had failed to establish the facts of the case and , furthermore , that he had left GPE before the opening of the criminal case against him in his home country .
CARDINAL . On DATE the NORP ORG notified the applicant that it had instructed ORG to examine his request .

CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE the Nizhniy NORP FMS informed the applicant that on DATE it had refused to examine the complaint , since the applicant did not meet the “ refugee ” definition .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against that decision to the NORP ORG , referring to the regional migration authority ’s failure to assess the risk of ill - treatment . In addition to his earlier submissions he provided references to articles from the local press published in DATE concerning the continuing practice of ill - treatment of detainees in GPE . The appeal was received by the NORP ORG on DATE . On DATE the NORP ORG accepted the applicant ’s complaint and remitted it to the regional migration authority for examination on the merits .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE ORG of the ORG High Commissioner for Refugees ( ORG ) informed the defence that the applicant met the criteria established by its statute and was eligible for international protection under its mandate .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG Novgorod ORG rejected the applicant ’s request for refugee status by a letter received by the applicant on DATE , citing CARDINAL grounds for the refusal : ( CARDINAL ) failure to meet the “ refugee ” definition ; and ( CARDINAL ) the inapplicability of LAW to individuals who had “ committed a serious criminal offence of a nonpolitical nature outside GPE before being admitted to GPE as a person requesting refugee status ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against that refusal , maintaining that the charges had been fabricated and pointing to the risk of illtreatment , with extensive references to reports by ORG and ORG , and information from ORG of ORG . He also requested an extension of DATE time - limit for lodging his appeal , since he had allegedly not been able to understand the contents of the letter of CARDINAL DATE because of his poor command in NORP , and his lawyer had explained the grounds for the refusal to him only on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the NORP ORG rejected the appeal . It noted that , according to information from ORG , the human rights situation in GPE was “ ambiguous ” . The dissemination of ideas of religious extremism and separatism constituted a criminal offence in that country . After the defeat of the ORG uprising the importing of NORP literature had been proscribed . The GPE leadership had an expressed intention to fine and put in jail individuals who worshipped outside the areas designated for that purpose . The NORP authorities considered that members of ORG and PERSON , a branch of PERSON - ut - GPE , had actively participated in the NORP events of DATE , and criminal proceedings against CARDINAL persons , including CARDINAL members of PERSON , were underway . Turning to the applicant ’s case , the ORG noted that the applicant had failed to apply for asylum in due time after his arrival in GPE and had referred to his poor command in NORP to justify that failure . However , the migration authority noted that , first , the applicant had performed military service in GPE , GPE , in DATE , which would have been impossible without an adequate knowledge of NORP , and second , he had received a temporary resident permit for GPE in DATE . Thus , the NORP ORG concluded that the applicant had provided false information about his language proficiency and that fact “ undermined confidence in the applicant and in the remainder of his submissions ” . The ORG concluded as follows :

“ Having analysed the applicant ’s submissions and the information provided by ORG and ORG of GPE on the situation in GPE and the activities of banned religious organisations , [ the NORP ORG ] finds no grounds to consider that the applicant would be persecuted on racial , religious , nationality , social or political grounds in the event of his return [ to the requesting country ] . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant challenged that decision in court . In written submissions and an oral statement made during the court hearing the defence reiterated the applicant ’s fear that , in the event of extradition to GPE , he would be subjected to torture with a view to extracting a confession from him in respect of offences he had not committed . He further stated that the ORG had failed to duly assess that risk . As to his limited command of NORP , he stated that he had performed his military service DATE prior to his arrest , that fluent NORP had not been necessary for obtaining the temporary residence permit and , furthermore , that his difficulty in understanding NORP had been confirmed in several hearings concerning his extradition and the extensions of his pretrial detention , where the courts had heard him in person and had agreed that he needed an interpreter ’s assistance .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE rejected that appeal . The court reiterated that the applicant had not complained of a risk of persecution in GPE and had not raised his wish to remain in GPE as a refugee until his arrest . His allegations of persecution for attending a mosque were ill - founded , given that the majority of the population of the destination country freely practised ORG . In addition , the court noted that the destination country had signed various international human rights treaties concerning , in particular , the protection of refugees . The court further endorsed the NORP ORG ’s decision as lawful , noting the applicant ’s failure to adduce “ convincing arguments to support his allegations of fear of unlawful persecution on religious grounds ” .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , maintaining the claims summarised in paragraph CARDINAL above and submitting in addition that the first - instance court had failed to assess the risk on the basis of all available information , as well as to address his counter - arguments to the ORG ’s conclusion regarding his command of the LANGUAGE language .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of DATE . The appeal court found that the migration authority had taken its decision in compliance with the existing procedure and that the firstinstance court had ORG endorsed the conclusion that no evidence of the applicant ’s persecution on religious grounds had been adduced , and noted that the defence had not referred to any new facts capable of altering that conclusion . The court also referred to several international human rights treaties signed by GPE and noted that on CARDINAL DATE ORG had lifted various sanctions , including an arms embargo , against that country on account of progress achieved in the human rights sphere and the abolition of the death penalty there .

CARDINAL . Following the applicant ’s arrest on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , on DATE the ORG Novgorod transport prosecutor ordered his placement in custody pending extradition . On DATE the ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal against the detention order . On DATE the Nizhniy ORG upheld decision on appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE , upon receipt of the formal request for the applicant ’s extradition ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the ORG GPE deputy transport prosecutor , by a separate decision , again ordered the applicant ’s detention pending extradition . It is unclear whether the decision was appealed against .
CARDINAL . It appears that at some point the ORG Novgorod transport prosecutor ’s office asked the court to extend the applicant ’s detention .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG examined that request , found that the latest extension of the applicant ’s detention had been granted on DATE [ sic ] , and the applicant could be held in custody on the basis of a prosecutor ’s order for a period not exceeding DATE . The court noted the receipt of the formal extradition request from the NORP authorities ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , observed that the extradition proceedings had not been completed , and decided that the applicant should remain in custody until DATE .
CARDINAL . The applicant ’s lawyer appealed , arguing , inter alia , that the applicant had been held in custody unlawfully since DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG dismissed the appeal and endorsed the extension of DATE .

DATE . On DATE the ORG of Nizhniy Novgorod Nizhniy GPE extended the applicant ’s detention pending extradition until DATE . On CARDINAL DATE the Nizhniy ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal of DATE and upheld the extension order .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG further extended the applicant ’s detention until DATE . The decision was upheld on appeal by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG , when examining the applicant ’s appeal against the extradition order ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) , authorised the extension of the applicant ’s detention until DATE . The court found no reason to apply a preventive measure other than detention , since it was necessary to ensure the applicant ’s extradition .

CARDINAL . On DATE , by an additional statement of appeal against the judgment of CARDINAL DATE , the defence challenged ORG findings in so far as they concerned the extension of the detention . He complained , in particular , about the overlap of the extension with the ruling of LOC of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE , deciding on the applicant ’s appeal against the extradition order ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , upheld the entirety of the lower court ’s findings without addressing the detention issue separately .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , by a separate decision , extended the applicant ’s detention until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG upheld the extension on appeal . ORG found there was no contradiction between the CARDINAL decisions of CARDINAL DATE issued by ORG and ORG since the first CARDINAL concerned the applicant ’s detention pending extradition , whilst the second one dealt with the lawfulness of the extradition order .
CARDINAL . On DATE the transport prosecutor ’s office lodged an application for a further extension of the applicant ’s detention with ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG examined the matter and granted an extension until DATE . According to the hearing transcript , the applicant requested the court to change the preventive measure in respect of him to CARDINAL of house arrest , and gave the address of a relative in GPE Novgorod where he could reside pursuant to the application of such a measure . He stated that before his arrest he had lived in PERSON and not in GPE , the place of his formal residence registration . He did not remember the exact address in GPE PERSON he had resided at . The applicant ’s lawyer stated at the hearing that the applicant had introduced an application with the ORG and that an interim measure had been applied to his case under Rule CARDINAL of ORG . The lawyer pointed to the similarly between the applicant ’s case and several others previously examined by ORG ( for instance , the case of PERSON and Others , cited above ) and stated that the applicant had a good chance of winning his case in GPE . The lawyer submitted that “ there exist[ed ] legal grounds for decreasing the amount of compensation , and even reducing it to CARDINAL ” if the preventive measure in respect of the applicant was changed to a milder one . The lawyer provided a full address in PERSON where the applicant could be placed under house arrest and specified that the applicant himself had by mistake cited the wrong street name .

CARDINAL . When granting the extension , ORG observed that the circumstances requiring the applicant ’s detention remained unchanged . The court noted that the extradition order in respect of the applicant had indeed become final but the extradition had been suspended pursuant to the application of Rule DATE by ORG , and therefore the extradition order could not be enforced . However , there existed a risk of the applicant ’s absconding if he was released . The court noted that the applicant was wanted for particularly serious offences , had been hiding from the NORP authorities , and measures were being taken to ensure his extradition which involved the application of international treaties ; therefore his case should be considered exceptional . His detention was in accordance with the domestic law . Various case documents demonstrated the reasonableness of the suspicion against him as regarded the well - foundedness of the accusations brought by the NORP authorities , but ORG was not competent to decide on that matter . It concluded that the extension of the applicant ’s detention was in compliance with LAW . The court further rejected the possibility of changing the preventive measure to house arrest , since the applicant had been unable to indicate a specific address where he could reside if such a measure was applied , or to provide any further details in support of his petition .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against the decision . In particular , he challenged ORG reference to the gravity of the charges against him and the exceptional nature of the case as immaterial . With reference to the PERSON case ( see PERSON v. GPE , DATE , § CARDINAL , Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINAL ) , he stated that no action had been taken with a view to his extradition since DATE , when the extradition order had become final , and ORG had failed to indicate any specific measures to be taken to enforce the extradition order after that date . He drew the court ’s attention to contradictory documents submitted by the NORP authorities and submitted that the charges were fabricated and unfounded .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . The court endorsed the firstinstance court ’s reasoning as lawful and well - founded . In particular , it upheld ORG findings as to the gravity of the charges against the applicant , the possibility of his absconding or obstructing justice , and the exceptional nature of his case . ORG observed that the lower court had reached its conclusions on the basis of all available material , including the information on the application pending before ORG . The court further upheld as reasonable the refusal to place the applicant under house arrest , since the address of his registration was no longer his place of residence , he had failed to give his latest place of residence in GPE , and he had been unable to provide either an address where he could he held under house arrest or any other details .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE LOC changed the preventive measure in respect of the applicant to house arrest , on account of the expiry of the maximum term for his detention pending extradition and in order to ensure the applicant ’s extradition , which was suspended at the time pursuant to the application of the interim measure by ORG . The applicant and his representative were present at the hearing . The court referred , in particular , to Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ( “ the CCrP ” ) . The house arrest order read as follows :

“ ... to prohibit [ the applicant ] from leaving his permanent place of residence at the address [ ... ] , communicating , without an investigator ’s prior consent , with suspects , accused , victims or other participants in the criminal case , and from sending and receiving correspondence , or using any means of communication . ”

CARDINAL . The court specified that the local transport prosecutor ’s office and ORG of ORG was to ensure supervision of the applicant ’s compliance with the restrictions imposed . The court further ordered the applicant ’s immediate release from detention and specified that the decision could be appealed against in ORG within DATE , and that the applicant could participate in the appeal hearing if he chose to appeal .
CARDINAL . The applicant did not appeal against the house arrest order .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant ’s lawyer lodged a petition ( ходатайство ) under Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG with the ORG Novgorod transport prosecutor asking him “ to lodge a petition with a court ” for the discontinuation of the applicant ’s house arrest . Referring to Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG , the lawyer submitted that the period the applicant had spent in detention should be counted towards the term of the house arrest , pointed out that the maximum period for the applicant ’s detention had expired on DATE , and claimed that further application of the preventive measure to him was therefore unlawful .
CARDINAL . On DATE the transport prosecutor ’s office notified the applicant of an extension of the time - limit for the examination of his request until CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE PERSON , the deputy transport prosecutor of GPE , rejected the applicant ’s request – which she referred to as “ a request to bring an extraordinary appeal ” ( « ходатайство о принесении протеста ORG ) DATE against the judgment of CARDINAL DATE . She noted that the court had examined all available material on the extradition procedure and taken a reasonable and lawful decision to place the applicant under house arrest in order to ensure his extradition , that there was no reason to change the preventive measure , and that the domestic law did not specify a maximum time - limit for house arrest . A copy of the decision was submitted to ORG . It appears that the applicant and his lawyer did not receive it .

CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE Mr NORP , Head of ORG of the ORG transport prosecutor ’s office , informed the applicant that there were no grounds to bring an extraordinary appeal and cited the same reasons as in the above decision .
DATE . On DATE the applicant challenged D. ’s refusal to request his release in LOC under LAW of the CCrP.

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected a complaint by the applicant about “ the refusal to bring an application for a change of the preventive measure in respect of the applicant ” , noting that the applicant had complained about the actions of NORP , who had not taken any decisions in the applicant ’s case , the refusal having in fact been issued by PERSON applicant did not appeal against that decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG GPE deputy transport prosecutor discontinued the applicant ’s house arrest on account of his placement in custody on DATE in connection with a criminal case against him in GPE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought a civil action against the transport prosecutor ’s office under Articles CARDINAL - CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure , requesting the court to order the transport prosecutor ’s office to quash the refusal of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE LOC refused to examine the civil complaint against the impugned prosecutor ’s decision , finding that the dispute at stake fell within the province of criminal rather than civil procedural law . It appears that the applicant did not appeal .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW DATE ( ORG no . CARDINAL ) , to which GPE is a party , provides as follows :
“ Extradition shall not be granted if the offence in respect of which it is requested is regarded by the requested ORG as a political offence or as an offence connected with a political offence .

The same rule shall apply if the requested ORG has substantial grounds for believing that a request for extradition for an ordinary criminal offence has been made for the purpose of prosecuting or punishing a person on account of his race , religion , nationality or political opinion , or that that person ’s position may be prejudiced for any of these reasons . ...
This article shall not affect any obligations which the Contracting Parties may have undertaken or may undertake under any other international convention of a multilateral character . ”
CARDINAL . When depositing the instrument of ratification on DATE , GPE made the following declaration :
“ GPE proceeds from the understanding that the provisions of LAW should be so applied as to ensure inevitable responsibility for offences under the provisions of the LAW .

The GPE proceeds from the understanding that legislation of GPE does not provide for the notion « political offences PERSON . In all cases when deciding on extradition GPE will not consider as « political offences » or « offences connected with political offences ORG along with offences , specified in LAW to the DATE LAW , in particular , the following acts :
h. ... other comparable crimes specified in the multilateral international treaties which GPE is a party to . ”

CARDINAL . For a summary of other relevant provisions concerning extradition proceedings and refugee status proceedings , see PERSON GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL - CARDINAL and CARDINAL - CARDINAL respectively , CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the ORG , as in force at the material time , provided that house arrest consisted of restricting a suspect ’s or an accused ’s freedom of movement , as well as forbidding him or her to ( CARDINAL ) communicate with certain persons , ( CARDINAL ) receive and send correspondence , and ( CARDINAL ) conduct conversations using any means of communication . A suspect or an accused could be put under house arrest on the grounds and in accordance with the procedure set out in LAW of the CCrP ( placement in custody DATE see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) , with due regard for the person ’s age , health , family status and other circumstances ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . A decision to place a suspect or an accused under house arrest was to specify the restrictions imposed and designate a supervisory authority to ensure that the restrictions were observed ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . In Decision ( Определение ) N CARDINAL-O - O of CARDINAL DATE ORG found that the applicable criminal procedure law , in so far as it provided that house arrest was an alternative to detention on remand , implied that a court decision on placement under house arrest should contain a specific and reasonable time - limit for the application of that preventive measure ( § CARDINAL of the Decision )

CARDINAL . By Ruling PERSON ) N CARDINAL of DATE , ORG of GPE reiterated the ORG ’s caselaw to the effect that the difference between deprivation of and restriction upon liberty is CARDINAL of degree or intensity , and not CARDINAL of nature or substance ( § CARDINAL of the Ruling ) . Having analysed the relevant provisions of the ORG governing house arrest and detention , taken together , as well as the nature of the restrictions applied to an individual in the case of house arrest , ORG found , in particular , that house arrest , like detention on remand , implied the compulsory isolation of an accused or a suspect from society , in a limited space , and the prevention of the person from working , moving freely and communicating with other persons . Thus , in view of the restrictions suffered , house arrest involved a direct restriction of a person ’s right to physical liberty and security . Therefore , the procedural guarantees in the case of house arrest should be the same as those applicable to detention on remand ( § CARDINAL of the Ruling ) .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court observed that LAW of the ORG , as in force at the material time , did not specify either the maximum period for house arrest , or instructions on how it should be applied or extended . ORG held as follows ( § CARDINAL of the Ruling ) :

“ Therefore , the provisions of LAW of the ORG , taken alone or in conjunction with other provisions of the Code , create uncertainty as regards the duration of house arrest , its extension , and the maximum time limit precluding any further extension of [ that preventive measure ] , and thus allow for the establishment of time - limits in respect of a restriction of the constitutional right to liberty and security of a person in an arbitrary manner and solely upon the decision [ of a law - enforcement authority ] . ”

CARDINAL . ORG declared Article CARDINAL of the CCrP unconstitutional in so far as it did not specify the period for which house arrest could be applied , the grounds and procedure for the extension or the maximum period for placement under house arrest .

CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE Article CARDINAL of the ORG was amended . LAW CARDINAL now stipulates that a period of house arrest may not exceed DATE . Where it is impossible to complete a preliminary investigation , and in the absence of grounds for amendment or annulment of the preventive measure , a court may extend that period within the procedure provided for in Article CARDINAL of the LAW stipulates that a period of detention on remand should be counted toward the period of the house arrest and the total length of house arrest and detention on remand may not exceed the maximum time - limit set out in LAW , irrespective of the order of application of these CARDINAL preventive measures .

CARDINAL . Custody may be ordered by a court on application by an investigator or a prosecutor if a person is charged with an offence carrying a sentence of DATE imprisonment , provided that a less restrictive preventive measure can not be used ( LAW CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . A period of detention pending investigation may not exceed DATE ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . A judge may extend that period DATE ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . Further extensions up to DATE , or in exceptional circumstances , DATE , may only be granted if the person is charged with serious or particularly serious criminal offences ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . No extension beyond DATE is permissible and the detainee must be released immediately ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . A period spent under house arrest should be counted towards the total period of detention ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . If the grounds serving as the basis for a preventive measure have changed , the preventive measure must be cancelled or amended . A decision to cancel or amend a preventive measure may be taken by an investigator , a prosecutor or a court ( Article CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . For a summary of other relevant CCrP provisions see Zokhidov , cited above , § CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the ORG provides that a judge ’s decision on detention is amenable to appeal before a higher court within DATE of its delivery . Having received the file , the second - instance court must examine the appeal lodged against the judge ’s detention decision within DATE . A decision by the second - instance court to annul the detention is to be executed immediately .

CARDINAL . Chapter CARDINAL of the ORG , as in force at the material time , set out the appeal procedure . Article CARDINAL of the ORG , as in force at the material time , established the scope for the examination of a case by an appeal court . It provided that the appeal court was to examine appeals with a view to verifying the lawfulness , validity and fairness of the judgment or other judicial decision of the first - instance court . An appeal court could also directly examine evidence , including additional material submitted by the parties ( LAW , as in force at the material time ) .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL , as in force at the material time , provided that the appeal court could take the following decisions : ( CARDINAL ) to dismiss the appeal and uphold the judgment or other judicial decision taken by the firstinstance court ; ( CARDINAL ) to quash the judgment or other judicial decision and discontinue the criminal proceedings ; ( CARDINAL ) to quash the judgment and remit the case for fresh examination to the first - instance court , or ( CARDINAL ) to amend the judgment or other judicial decision taken by the first - instance court .

CARDINAL . A violation of procedural law where a party to the proceedings had been deprived of or restricted in the exercise of his or her procedural rights , or where a procedure had not been complied with , or where there had been another defect which had influenced or could have influenced the fairness of the proceedings , constituted a ground for the quashing or amendment of a judicial decision ( Article CARDINAL of the ORG , as in force at the material time ) .

CARDINAL . Chapter CARDINAL of the ORG provides that suspects , defendants and their representatives may petition officials for taking procedural decisions that would secure rights and legitimate interests of the petitioner ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . A petition may be lodged at any stage of the criminal proceedings ( LAW ) , in particular , with the court ( LAW ) . It may be also lodged by a prosecutor ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Chapter CARDINAL of the CCrP ( “ Complaints about the acts and decisions of courts and officials involved in criminal proceedings ” ) provides for judicial review of decisions and acts or failures to act by an investigator or a prosecutor that are capable of adversely affecting the constitutional rights or freedoms of parties to criminal proceedings ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Chapter CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure sets out the procedure for judicial review of complaints about decisions , acts or omissions of ORG authorities and officials . A citizen may lodge a complaint about an act or decision by any ORG authority which he believes has breached his rights or freedoms either with a court of general jurisdiction or by sending it to the directly superior official or authority ( Article CARDINAL ) . The complaint may concern , in particular , any decision , act or omission which has violated rights or freedoms , or has impeded the exercise of rights or freedoms , of the citizen ( Article CARDINAL).The complaint must be lodged within DATE on which the citizen learnt of the breach of his rights .

CARDINAL . For a summary of the legal provisions concerning the database code - named “ Search - Highway ” ( “ Розыск-Магистраль ” ) and establishing the procedure for its operation , see PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL , DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of Federal Law No . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE on the Procedure for Entering and Leaving GPE ( “ LAW ” ) provides that a foreign national ’s leaving of GPE may be restricted where criminal proceedings are pending against him or her , until a final decision in those proceedings is adopted .
CARDINAL . For a summary of the recent reports on GPE by the ORG institutions and by NGOs , see Zokhidov , cited above , § § CARDINAL - CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . For a summary of ORG texts on the duty to cooperate with the ORG , the right to individual petition , and interim measures , see PERSON , cited above , § § CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . For a summary of ORG decisions under LAW on related cases concerning GPE adopted DATE and DATE , see PERSON , cited above , § § DATE .

CARDINAL . At the CARDINALth meeting of ORG held on DATE , ORG adopted the following decision in the wake of yet another incident involving allegations of disappearance of the applicant in respect of whom the interim measure was indicated by ORG ( CM / Del / Dec(CARDINAL)CARDINAL/HCARDINAL - CARDINALE ):
“ The Deputies ,
Recalling the decisions adopted at their ORG meeting ( DATE ) ( DH ) and CARDINAL meeting ( DATE ) ( DH ) in the PERSON group of cases against GPE ( see the list below ) ,

CARDINAL . NORP noted with grave concern that a further incident involving allegations of kidnapping and illegal transfer of an applicant protected by an interim measure indicated by ORG under Rule DATE has been reported [ ... ]
CARDINAL . NORP strongly insisted that light be shed on this incident and on the fate of the applicant as quickly as possible ;

CARDINAL . NORP consequently insisted again on the pressing need to adopt as of now measures to ensure an immediate and effective protection of the applicants in a similar situation against kidnappings and irregular removals from the national territory ;
CARDINAL . recalled in this context the letter sent by the Chairman of ORG to the Minister of ORG of GPE ;

CARDINAL . NORP agreed that a draft interim resolution will be considered in the light of progress that would have been made , including the updated action plan submitted by the NORP authorities ; this text will be circulated in the draft revised order of business of their CARDINAL meeting ( DATE ) ( DH ) . ”
